Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Undergraduate Students' Epistemology and Expectations of Experimental Physics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Within many disciplines, concerns are frequently raised about how effective laboratory courses are at connecting experimental processes with theoretical concepts, and more generally bridging the gap between the practices of the classroom laboratory and the practices of the professional scientific research and engineering laboratories. Calls to transform laboratory courses are coming from a wide variety of stakeholders, including: the physics education community; the life sciences community; and national science policy-making bodies promoting the retention of STEM majors, the development of the STEM workforce, and updated guidelines for the laboratory curriculum. Recommendations advocate that students should develop habits of mind, experimental strategies, enthusiasm, and confidence in research through improved laboratory courses. Towards these goals this research project will advance understanding of how to support students in developing experimental skills and understanding of the experimental process, through probing students' attitudes and instructors' expectations. Evaluation tools will also be developed to enable instructors to iteratively improve their courses and to give researchers insights into the effects of different course modifications on student learning.

To advance understanding of how to support students in developing experimental skills and understanding of the experimental process, the research team will probe students' attitudes and instructors' expectations. The student and instructor data will be gathered utilizing the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey for Experimental Physics (E-CLASS) survey. An online platform that allows instructors to administer the survey and analyze their data automatically and seamlessly thus adding an automated survey administration and reporting system will be developed. This will allow feedback from users in order that current statements in the survey are evaluated for their usefulness. Responses from users will allow tailoring of the survey to meet the majority of instructors' goals and the report sent to back to instructors will be refined. Information on how instructors are using the data will be ascertained, e.g., how they are using it to reform courses and the details of the interventions attempted. Finally building off the ideas of institutional and instructional change a "A Guide to the E CLASS: Use, Interpretation and Course Modifications" will be developed. Through these means the use of the survey will be increased, a system will be developed to make the administration of the survey more sustainable in the long term, results will be used to help instructors tailor their courses to achieve individual goals, the validity and reliability of the survey will be increased, and progress towards answering several research questions about training students in experimental physics will be made. The project will be evaluated both internally and externally in both a formative and summative manner to ensure project success in making direct progress towards the goals. The project will include an advisory board of key professionals who will provide formative feedback and advising on key decisions. In addition, knowledge gained and the platform developed will be shared with the education research community, as it may be a new model for dissemination of these types of assessment tools. Dissemination will occur via submission of publications to journals that are instructor focused (e.g., AJP, Physics Teacher and Physical Review Special Topics-PER.) Results will also be disseminated through faculty workshops run by AAPT the American Astronomical Society and APS and the Annual Physics Department Chairs conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Science education relies on weaving together core disciplinary ideas (e.g., the facts and theories) with scientific practices (e.g., the methods of science).  Laboratory classes are important learning environments because they can engage students in a wide range of practices through the available scientific equipment and lab space. Such environments facilitate designing and carrying out experiments, collecting and analyzing data, collaboratively solving problems, troubleshooting, asking question, and more. However, learning in laboratory courses is also complex because lab courses have diverse goals and not standardized between institutions. There is a need for new research on how labs impact students and a need for new assessment tools for lab courses. This study examined how lab courses impact students' personal epistemologies (i.e., their beliefs about knowing) as they relate to experimental physics. 

Most prior research on personal epistemologies has been limited to lecture-format courses where data, evidence, measurements, uncertainty, and experimental design play little role. The assessment tools and theoretical frameworks we have developed provide instructors with practical ways to assess whether or not these highly relevant goals are being met.

Through this collaborative project with the University of Colorado Boulder, several outcomes were realized: (1) a new online survey administration platform was developed that automated the administration of the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey for Experimental Physics (E-CLASS), which enabled a nationwide distribution of the survey to 75 institutions and over 7000 students, (2) new data was collected, analyzed, and published relating to the validity and interpretation of E-CLASS results, (3) supplemental open-ended assessments were developed to explore students' ideas in greater depth,  and (4) open-ended assessment results were analyzed and published.

One interesting finding related to students' beliefs about knowing dealt with the relationship between theoretical and experimental sources of knowledge. Both sources of knowledge are essential for scientific progress, but we were curious how students perceived their relationship. At the introductory level, many students had ideas that were "theory-centric." From such a perspective, the most important and most accurate ways of knowing were expressed theoretically (e.g., in precise mathematical equations).  Students with a theory-centric view described laboratory activities as supplemental experiences that help them understand important theoretical ideas better. The theory-centric view also neglected the role of labs in developing students' abilities in scientific practices, such as taking measurements or analyzing and interpreting data. Further, students with a theory-centric view said physics experiments are only used to test or demonstrate theories, which neglects the role of experiments in discovering new things and also neglects using theories and models as a means to explain or predict the outcomes of new experiments. 

A second result dealt with students' ideas about how the validity of scientific knowledge could be established. What were students' criteria for believing a result to be true or accurate? For many introductory students with a theory-centric view, a result was considered trustworthy or valid if it agreed with a theoretical prediction. In other words, the theory is always right, but sometimes the experiment does not do what it should. This view contrasted with more process-based explanations given by upper-division undergraduate and PhD students, such as establishing validity through repeating measurements, understanding the technical limitations of equipment, comparing with alternate measurement approaches, and quantifying uncertainty in the measurement.

Both examples show how science courses may unintentionally influence students' views about what it means to engage in scientific work. The results also highlight why it is important to assess aspects of a course beyond the core content, such as students' personal epistemologies and their developing proficiency in scientific practices.


Broader Impacts

This research has a direct impact on education in STEM, workforce development, and developing a STEM literate citizenry. There is a growing awareness within science education that science courses should emphasize how science is done (e.g., the scientific practices) in addition to the disciplinary core ideas. Our research provides assessment tools (the E-CLASS and the open-ended survey) along with findings that help faculty understand how physics courses shape students' views about science.  Specifically, these assessments could be used to develop science courses that more explicitly emphasize the role of evidence and data equally with theoretical models. 

Many of the most complex sociotechnical issues in society, which are related to health, the environment, and the economy, are addressed through solutions based on theoretical models and experimental evidence and observations. If lab courses misrepresent science, either by being too theory-centric or procedural, we will have missed an opportunity to equip our students with the resources to face these challenges, sort through the various ideas, and make well-reasoned decisions on their own.
